title: Authors and Citation
text: Peter Lert. Author, maintainer, copyright holder.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Lert P (2026). BAQM: Babson Analytics Quantitative Methods Tools. R package version 0.1.4, https://github.com/CPA-wrk/BAQM.
code: @Manual{,   title = {BAQM: Babson Analytics and Quantitative Methods Tools},   author = {Peter Lert},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.1.4},   url = {https://github.com/CPA-wrk/BAQM}, }

what: Babson Analytics and Quantitative Methods Tools
title: Babson Analytics and Quantitative Methods Tools
text: BAQM supplies functions developed Babson College instructors AQM 1000 AQM 2000 courses using R curriculum. primary functions provide: sumry.df() - summary descriptive statistics data frames, allowing numeric factor variables, wide long formats. sumry.lm() - expanded statistics enhanced formatting summarize linear model results. lm_plot.4way() - multiple diagnostic plots linear models using ggplot, including 4--1 summary graphic. sumry.regsubsets() - compact “best subsets” linear model reports analytics regsubsets function leaps package.

title: Babson Analytics and Quantitative Methods Tools
text: can install development version BAQM GitHub :
code: install.packages("pak") pak::pak("CPA-wrk/BAQM")

title: Babson Analytics and Quantitative Methods Tools
text: examples use built-R data sets iris, swiss, mtcars, show: brief statistical summaries data sets iris swiss, concise best-subsets report regression modeling Fertility swiss, expanded statistical summaries linear models Sepal Length iris miles per gallon mtcars, 4-way diagnostic plot mtcars model. (Variable names truncated swiss narrow output.)
code: library(leaps) library(BAQM) # sumry(iris) # Includes non-numeric variable #>          Sepal.Length  Sepal.Width  Petal.Length  Petal.Width     Species #> n.val             150          150           150          150         150 #> n.na                0            0             0            0           0 #> min               4.3            2             1          0.1  n.lvl  : 3 #> Q1                5.1          2.7           1.6          0.2  setosa :50 #> median            5.8            3          4.35          1.3  versclr:50 #> mean            5.843        3.057         3.758        1.199  virginc:50 #> Q3               6.45          3.4           5.1          1.8             #> max               7.9          4.4           6.9          2.5             #> std.dev        0.8281       0.4359         1.765       0.7622 # names(swiss) # Show original variable names #> [1] "Fertility"        "Agriculture"      "Examination"      "Education"        #> [5] "Catholic"         "Infant.Mortality" names(swiss) <- substr(names(swiss), 1, 4) # Narrows output sumry(swiss) #>           Fert   Agri   Exam   Educ   Cath   Infa #> n.val       47     47     47     47     47     47 #> n.na         0      0      0      0      0      0 #> min         35    1.2      3      1   2.15   10.8 #> Q1        64.4   35.3     12      6   5.16     18 #> median    70.4   54.1     16      8  15.14     20 #> mean     70.14  50.66  16.49  10.98  41.14  19.94 #> Q3        79.3   67.8     22   12.5   93.4   22.2 #> max       92.5   89.7     37     53    100   26.6 #> std.dev  12.49  22.71  7.978  9.615   41.7  2.913 regs <- regsubsets(Fert ~ ., data = swiss, nbest = 3) sumry(regs) #>                                                                                                                                                      #> Call: (function (...)                                                                                                                                #>       rmarkdown::render(...))(input = base::quote("/Users/peter/Library/CloudStorage/OneDrive-centerpointanalytics.com/CPA_wrk/R/BAQM/README.Rmd"),  #>           output_options = base::quote(list(html_preview = FALSE)),                                                                                  #>           quiet = base::quote(TRUE))                                                                                                                 #>    _k_i.best    rsq  adjr2       see    cp Agri Exam Educ Cath Infa #> 1   1  ( 1 ) 0.4406 0.4282  9.446029 35.20              *           #> 2   1  ( 2 ) 0.4172 0.4042  9.642000 38.48         *                #> 3   1  ( 3 ) 0.2150 0.1976 11.189945 66.75                   *      #> 4   2  ( 1 ) 0.5745 0.5552  8.331442 18.49              *    *      #> 5   2  ( 2 ) 0.5648 0.5450  8.426136 19.85              *         * #> 6   2  ( 3 ) 0.5363 0.5152  8.697447 23.83         *              * #> 7   3  ( 1 ) 0.6625 0.6390  7.505417  8.18              *    *    * #> 8   3  ( 2 ) 0.6423 0.6173  7.727757 11.01    *         *    *      #> 9   3  ( 3 ) 0.6191 0.5925  7.973957 14.25         *    *         * #> 10  4  ( 1 ) 0.6993 0.6707  7.168166  5.03    *         *    *    * #> 11  4  ( 2 ) 0.6639 0.6319  7.579356  9.99         *    *    *    * #> 12  4  ( 3 ) 0.6498 0.6164  7.736422 11.96    *    *    *    *      #> 13  5  ( 1 ) 0.7067 0.6710  7.165369  6.00    *    *    *    *    * # mdl <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ ., data = iris) sumry(mdl) #>  #> Summary Statistics: #>                  Value      Performance    Measure  Err(Resids)    Metric #> Observations =     150      R-Squared =    0.86731       MAPE =  0.041785 #> F-Statistic =   188.25      Adj-R2 =       0.86271       MAD  =   0.24286 #> Pr(b's=0) =     <2e-16 ***  Std.Err.Est =  0.30683       RMSE =   0.30063 #>  #> Analysis of Variance: #>                Deg.Frdm  Sum.of.Sqs  Mean.Sum.Sqs  F.statistic  p-value(F)     #> Regression            5      88.612     17.722370       188.25      <2e-16 *** #> Error(Resids)       144      13.556      0.094142                              #> Total               149     102.168                                            #>  #> Coefficients: #>                     Coefficient  Std.Error   t-stat   p-value          VIF #> (Intercept)             2.17127   0.279794   7.7602  1.43e-12 ***          #> Sepal.Width             0.49589   0.086070   5.7615  4.87e-08 ***   2.2275 #> Petal.Length            0.82924   0.068528  12.1009   < 2e-16 ***  23.1616 #> Petal.Width            -0.31516   0.151196  -2.0844   0.03889  *   21.0214 #> Species_versicolor     -0.72356   0.240169  -3.0127   0.00306 **   20.4234 #> Species_virginica      -1.02350   0.333726  -3.0669   0.00258 **   39.4344 #>                                                                       #> Signif.Levels:  0 '***' 0.001 '** ' 0.01 ' * ' 0.05 ' . ' 0.1 '   ' 1 #>                                                                  #> Summary of   Min       1Q      Mean    Median     3Q      Max    #> Residuals: -0.7942  -0.2187   <3e-14  0.008987  0.2025   0.731   #>                                                    #> Call:  lm(formula = Sepal.Length ~ ., data = iris) # mdl <- lm(mpg ~ hp + qsec, data = mtcars) sumry(mdl) #>  #> Summary Statistics: #>                    Value      Performance    Measure  Err(Resids)  Metric #> Observations =        32      R-Squared =    0.63688       MAPE =  0.1448 #> F-Statistic =     25.431      Adj-R2 =       0.61183       MAD  =  2.6984 #> Pr(b's=0) =     4.18e-07 ***  Std.Err.Est =    3.755       RMSE =  3.5746 #>  #> Analysis of Variance: #>                Deg.Frdm  Sum.of.Sqs  Mean.Sum.Sqs  F.statistic  p-value(F)     #> Regression            2      717.15        358.58       25.431    4.18e-07 *** #> Error(Resids)        29      408.89         14.10                              #> Total                31     1126.05                                            #>  #> Coefficients: #>              Coefficient  Std.Error   t-stat   p-value         VIF #> (Intercept)    48.323705  11.103306   4.3522  0.000153 ***         #> hp             -0.084593   0.013933  -6.0715  1.31e-06 ***  2.0063 #> qsec           -0.886580   0.534585  -1.6584  0.108007      2.0063 #>                                                                       #> Signif.Levels:  0 '***' 0.001 '** ' 0.01 ' * ' 0.05 ' . ' 0.1 '   ' 1 #>                                                            #> Summary of   Min     1Q    Median   Mean     3Q      Max   #> Residuals: -5.178  -2.603  -0.5098 <6e-15   1.287   8.718  #>                                                     #> Call:  lm(formula = mpg ~ hp + qsec, data = mtcars) lm_plot.4way(mdl)

what: BAQM: Babson Analytics and Quantitative Methods Tools — BAQM-package
title: BAQM: Babson Analytics and Quantitative Methods Tools — BAQM-package
text: Instructor-developed tools Analytics Quantitative Methods (AQM) courses Babson College. Included compact descriptive statistics data frames lists, expanded reporting graphics linear regressions, formatted reports best subsets analyses.

title: BAQM: Babson Analytics and Quantitative Methods Tools — BAQM-package
text: Maintainer: Peter Lert plert@babson.edu [copyright holder]

what: Create a Four-Panel Regression Assumptions Plot — lm_plot.4way
title: Create a Four-Panel Regression Assumptions Plot — lm_plot.4way
text: Generates 4-panel diagnostic plot multiple regression model, including: 1) Fitted values vs. observed values (check non-linearity), 2) Quantile–Quantile plot residuals (check non-normality), 3) Residuals vs. fitted values (check heteroskedasticity), 4) Autocorrelation time series otherwise influence plot (leverage also available).

title: Create a Four-Panel Regression Assumptions Plot — lm_plot.4way
code: lm_plot.4way(   mdl,   ...,   is.ts = FALSE,   pred.intvl = TRUE,   pval.SW = FALSE,   pval.BP = FALSE,   pval.DW = FALSE,   cook.loess = FALSE,   rtn.all = FALSE,   plt.nms = c("fit", "var", "qq", ifelse(is.ts, "ac", "infl")),   parms = list() )

title: Create a Four-Panel Regression Assumptions Plot — lm_plot.4way
text: mdl fitted model object (typically lm). ... Additional arguments (currently used). .ts Logical; TRUE data time series, FALSE otherwise. pred.intvl Logical; plot prediction interval fitted vs observed. pval.SW Logical; include Shapiro–Wilk p-value qq  plot. pval.BP Logical; include Breusch–Pagan p-value var plot. pval.DW Logical; include Durbin–Watson p-value ac  plot. cook.loess Logical; overlay Cook's distance loess curve infl  plot. rtn.Logical; return plots parameters (vs. 4-way plot ). plt.nms Character vector panels plot. Defaults fit, var, qq, ac/infl depending .ts (Order: start upper left, continue clockwise) parms List overrides plot formatting parameters (see lm_plot.parms).

title: Create a Four-Panel Regression Assumptions Plot — lm_plot.4way
text: ggplot object representing 4-way diagnostic panel.   Optionally invisibly returns list containing: p_4way – combined plot, elements passed individual plot functions.

title: Create a Four-Panel Regression Assumptions Plot — lm_plot.4way
text: function high-level wrapper calls internal plotting functions (lm_plot.fit, lm_plot.var, lm_plot.qq, either lm_plot.ac lm_plot.infl) assembles outputs combined plot_grid.

title: Create a Four-Panel Regression Assumptions Plot — lm_plot.4way
code: fit <- lm(mpg ~ wt + hp, data = mtcars) lm_plot.4way(fit, is.ts = FALSE, pval.SW = TRUE)  fit <- lm(Employed ~ ., data = longley) lm_plot.4way(fit, is.ts = TRUE, pval.DW = TRUE)

what: Plot Residuals vs. Observation Order (Autocorrelation Check) — lm_plot.ac
title: Plot Residuals vs. Observation Order (Autocorrelation Check) — lm_plot.ac
text: Creates plot residuals sequence/order observations visually assess independence detect autocorrelation. Outliers labeled default. Optionally includes p-value result Durbin–Watson test autocorrelation.

title: Plot Residuals vs. Observation Order (Autocorrelation Check) — lm_plot.ac
code: lm_plot.ac(   mdl,   ...,   pval.DW = FALSE,   parms = lm_plot.parms(mdl),   df = lm_plot.df(mdl, parms = parms) )

title: Plot Residuals vs. Observation Order (Autocorrelation Check) — lm_plot.ac
text: mdl fitted model object (typically lm). ... Additional arguments (currently used). pval.DW (logical, default = FALSE) Option show Durbin-Watson p-value plot. parms list plotting parameters, usually lm_plot.parms(). df Data frame augmented model data. Defaults lm_plot.df(mdl).

title: Plot Residuals vs. Observation Order (Autocorrelation Check) — lm_plot.ac
text: ggplot object representing residuals vs. order plot. Included attribute "parm" list containing: lim Plotted limits x y axes, pval.DW Option show Durbin-Watson p-value, DW htest object Durbin-Watson test results.

title: Plot Residuals vs. Observation Order (Autocorrelation Check) — lm_plot.ac
text: Points colored shaped according whether residual outliers (determined Tukey's boxplot rule). function can label points using ggrepel parm$pts$id$outl parm$pts$id$reg set TRUE.

title: Plot Residuals vs. Observation Order (Autocorrelation Check) — lm_plot.ac
code: fit <- lm(res ~ ., data = data.frame(time = time(austres), res = austres)) lm_plot.ac(fit, pval.DW = TRUE)

what: Augment Model Data for Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.df
title: Augment Model Data for Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.df
text: Generates augmented data frame linear model object, including fitted values, residuals, leverage, Cook's distance, prediction intervals, outlier/influence flags. function prepares model diagnostics plotting.

title: Augment Model Data for Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.df
code: lm_plot.df(mdl, parms = lm_plot.parms(mdl))

title: Augment Model Data for Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.df
text: mdl object class lm, representing fitted linear model. parms List plotting parameters, usually lm_plot.parms().

title: Augment Model Data for Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.df
text: data frame augmented diagnostic variables, one row per observation.

title: Augment Model Data for Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.df
text: returned data frame contains key statistics observation: .id: Observation identifier .sequence: Sequence index .obs: Observed values .fits: Fitted/predicted values .resid: Residuals .se.fit: Estimated standard error fitted (mean) value .lower.pi: Lower bound 95% prediction interval fitted value .upper.pi: Upper bound 95% prediction interval fitted value .std.resid: Standardized residuals .stud.resid: Studentized residuals .cooksd: Cook's distance .hat: Leverage (diagonal hat matrix) .quantile: Theoretical normal quantile residuals ..outl: Flag residual outlier ("outl" "reg") ..infl: Flag influential point ("infl" "outl" "reg") ..lev: Flag high leverage point ("lev" "infl" "reg")

title: Augment Model Data for Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.df

what: Plot Observed vs. Fitted Values to Check Linearity — lm_plot.fit
title: Plot Observed vs. Fitted Values to Check Linearity — lm_plot.fit
text: Generates scatter plot fitted values versus observed values linear model, identification outlier points optional prediction interval. plot includes reference line y = x assessing linearity.

title: Plot Observed vs. Fitted Values to Check Linearity — lm_plot.fit
code: lm_plot.fit(   mdl,   ...,   pred.intvl = TRUE,   parms = lm_plot.parms(mdl),   df = lm_plot.df(mdl, parms = parms) )

title: Plot Observed vs. Fitted Values to Check Linearity — lm_plot.fit
text: mdl fitted model object (typically lm). ... Additional arguments (currently used). pred.intvl (logical, default = TRUE) Option show prediction interval bounds fitted values. parms List plotting parameters, usually lm_plot.parms(). df Data frame augmented model data. Defaults lm_plot.df(mdl).

title: Plot Observed vs. Fitted Values to Check Linearity — lm_plot.fit
text: ggplot object representing fitted vs. observed plot. Included attribute "parm" list containing: lim Plotted limits x y axes, pred.intvl Option show prediction interval,

title: Plot Observed vs. Fitted Values to Check Linearity — lm_plot.fit
text: plot visualizes fitted versus observed values, includes diagonal reference line, marks outliers, can optionally display prediction intervals. Outlier regular points can labeled. plot useful visually assessing linearity model fit quality.

title: Plot Observed vs. Fitted Values to Check Linearity — lm_plot.fit
code: mdl <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width, data = iris) lm_plot.fit(mdl)

what: Plot Leverage vs. Fitted Values to Visualize Inflential Observations — lm_plot.infl
title: Plot Leverage vs. Fitted Values to Visualize Inflential Observations — lm_plot.infl
text: Creates plot leverage values versus linear fitted values, including identification points large Cook's distance, visualize high-leverage influential observations.

title: Plot Leverage vs. Fitted Values to Visualize Inflential Observations — lm_plot.infl
code: lm_plot.infl(   mdl,   ...,   parms = lm_plot.parms(mdl),   df = lm_plot.df(mdl, parms = parms) )

title: Plot Leverage vs. Fitted Values to Visualize Inflential Observations — lm_plot.infl
text: mdl fitted model object (typically lm). ... Additional arguments (currently used). parms List plotting parameters, usually lm_plot.parms(). df Data frame augmented model data. Defaults lm_plot.df(mdl).

title: Plot Leverage vs. Fitted Values to Visualize Inflential Observations — lm_plot.infl
text: ggplot object representing comb plot residuals vs sequence, indicating influential points. Included attribute "parms" list containing: lim Plotted limits x y axes.

title: Plot Leverage vs. Fitted Values to Visualize Inflential Observations — lm_plot.infl
text: plot visualizes calculated leverage individual data points, defined diagonal element 'hat' matrix, function fitted values implicitly relative location field predictor variables, threshold value high leverage indicated. addition, Cook's distance can used label influential points, along outlier regular points.

title: Plot Leverage vs. Fitted Values to Visualize Inflential Observations — lm_plot.infl
code: mdl <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width, data = iris) result <- lm_plot.infl(mdl)

what: Plot Standard Residuals vs. Leverage with Cook's Distance Contours — lm_plot.lev
title: Plot Standard Residuals vs. Leverage with Cook's Distance Contours — lm_plot.lev
text: Creates plot standard residuals versus leverage values, including Cook's distance contours visualize influential observations.

title: Plot Standard Residuals vs. Leverage with Cook's Distance Contours — lm_plot.lev
code: lm_plot.lev(   mdl,   ...,   cook.loess = FALSE,   parms = lm_plot.parms(mdl),   df = lm_plot.df(mdl, parms = parms) )

title: Plot Standard Residuals vs. Leverage with Cook's Distance Contours — lm_plot.lev
text: mdl fitted model object (typically lm). ... Additional arguments (currently used). cook.loess Option (logical, default = FALSE) indicates whether show loess curve Cook's distances plot. parms List plotting parameters, usually lm_plot.parms(). df Data frame augmented model data. Defaults lm_plot.df(mdl).

title: Plot Standard Residuals vs. Leverage with Cook's Distance Contours — lm_plot.lev
text: ggplot object representing standardized residuals vs leverage plot. Included attribute "parms" list containing: lim Plotted limits x y axes, cook.loess Option show loess curve Cook's distances.

title: Plot Standard Residuals vs. Leverage with Cook's Distance Contours — lm_plot.lev
text: plot displays standardized residuals leverage, overlays Cook's distance contours, marks outliers based residuals Cook's distance. Outlier influential points can labeled, loess fit line optionally added.

title: Plot Standard Residuals vs. Leverage with Cook's Distance Contours — lm_plot.lev
code: mdl <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width, data = iris) lm_plot.lev(mdl)

what: Set or Retrieve Default Plot Parameters for Model Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.parms
title: Set or Retrieve Default Plot Parameters for Model Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.parms
text: Initializes updates list plot element parameters use model diagnostic plotting functions. required parameter missing invalid, default value supplied.

title: Set or Retrieve Default Plot Parameters for Model Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.parms
code: lm_plot.parms(mdl, parms = list())

title: Set or Retrieve Default Plot Parameters for Model Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.parms
text: mdl object class lm. parms list plot parameters. missing invalid entries replaced defaults.

title: Set or Retrieve Default Plot Parameters for Model Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.parms
text: list plot element parameters defaults filled missing invalid entries.

title: Set or Retrieve Default Plot Parameters for Model Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.parms
text: returned list contains parameters points (size, color, shape), lines (type, color, size), options plot features, Cook's distance/Influence contours, seed values sampling functions. used lm_plot.* functions control plot appearance annotation. Key defaults include: pts: Properties points (size, color, shape, outlier flags) lins: Properties lines (type, color, size) cook: Cook's distance contour settings (points, levels, line type) infl: Influence line settings (line type) See function code full list available settings default values.

title: Set or Retrieve Default Plot Parameters for Model Diagnostic Plots — lm_plot.parms
code: # Retrieve default parameters parms <- lm_plot.parms(mdl = lm(Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width, data = iris)) # Set custom color for regular points parms <- lm_plot.parms(mdl = lm(Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width, data = iris),                        parms = list(pts = list(colr = list(reg = "blue"))))

what: Q-Q Plot of Residuals to Assess Normality — lm_plot.qq
title: Q-Q Plot of Residuals to Assess Normality — lm_plot.qq
text: Produces Q-Q plot residuals linear model test normality, optionally annotating outlier points adding Shapiro-Wilk test p-value.

title: Q-Q Plot of Residuals to Assess Normality — lm_plot.qq
code: lm_plot.qq(   mdl,   ...,   pval.SW = FALSE,   parms = lm_plot.parms(mdl),   df = lm_plot.df(mdl, parms = parms) )

title: Q-Q Plot of Residuals to Assess Normality — lm_plot.qq
text: mdl fitted model object (typically lm). ... Additional arguments (currently used). pval.SW (logical, default = FALSE) indicates whether include Shapiro-Wilk p-value plot. parms List plotting parameters, usually lm_plot.parms(). df Data frame augmented model data. Defaults lm_plot.df(mdl).

title: Q-Q Plot of Residuals to Assess Normality — lm_plot.qq
text: ggplot object representing quantile-quantile plot. Included attribute "parm" list containing: lim Plotted limits x y axes, pval.SW Option show Shapiro-Wilk p-value, DW htest object Shapiro-Wilk test results.

title: Q-Q Plot of Residuals to Assess Normality — lm_plot.qq
text: plot visualizes distribution residuals theoretical normal quantiles. Points colored shaped outlier status, reference Q-Q line added. Optionally, outlier regular points can labeled. enabled, Shapiro-Wilk normality test p-value displayed.

title: Q-Q Plot of Residuals to Assess Normality — lm_plot.qq
code: mdl <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width, data = iris) lm_plot.qq(mdl)

what: Plot Residuals vs. Fitted Values to Assess Homoskedasticity — lm_plot.var
title: Plot Residuals vs. Fitted Values to Assess Homoskedasticity — lm_plot.var
text: Produces scatter plot residuals fitted values linear model, highlighting outlier points optionally displaying Breusch-Pagan test p-value heteroskedasticity.

title: Plot Residuals vs. Fitted Values to Assess Homoskedasticity — lm_plot.var
code: lm_plot.var(   mdl,   ...,   pval.BP = FALSE,   parms = lm_plot.parms(mdl),   df = lm_plot.df(mdl, parms = parms) )

title: Plot Residuals vs. Fitted Values to Assess Homoskedasticity — lm_plot.var
text: mdl fitted model object (typically lm). ... Additional arguments (currently used). pval.BP (logical, default = FALSE) option include Breusch-Pagan p-value plot. parms List plotting parameters, usually lm_plot.parms(). df Data frame augmented model data. Defaults lm_plot.df(mdl).

title: Plot Residuals vs. Fitted Values to Assess Homoskedasticity — lm_plot.var
text: ggplot object representing residuals versus fitted values plot. Included attribute "parms" list containing: lim Plotted limits x y axes, pval.BP Option show Breusch-Pagan p-value, BP htest object Breusch-Pagan test results.

title: Plot Residuals vs. Fitted Values to Assess Homoskedasticity — lm_plot.var
text: plot visualizes residuals versus fitted values assess homoskedasticity (constant variance). Points colored shaped outlier status, outlier/regular points can labeled. Breusch-Pagan test heteroskedasticity run , enabled, p-value annotates plot.

title: Plot Residuals vs. Fitted Values to Assess Homoskedasticity — lm_plot.var
code: mdl <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width, data = iris) lm_plot.var(mdl, pval.BP = TRUE)

what: Identify Outliers Using Boxplot Heuristic — outlier
title: Identify Outliers Using Boxplot Heuristic — outlier
text: Detects outliers numeric vector using boxplot heuristic (default, outside 1.5 times IQR 1st 3rd quartiles). Handles missing values (NA) automatically.

title: Identify Outliers Using Boxplot Heuristic — outlier
code: outlier(x, coef = 1.5, rpt = FALSE)

title: Identify Outliers Using Boxplot Heuristic — outlier
text: x Numeric vector outliers detected. coef Numeric value boxplot heuristic coefficient (default 1.5). Higher values result fewer points classified outliers. rpt Logical. FALSE (default), returns logical vector indicating elements x outliers. TRUE, returns calculated lower upper limits outlier detection, identified x < rpt[1] | x > rpt[2].

title: Identify Outliers Using Boxplot Heuristic — outlier
text: rpt = FALSE, returns logical vector indicating outliers. rpt = TRUE, returns numeric vector length 2 giving lower upper limits outlier detection

title: Identify Outliers Using Boxplot Heuristic — outlier
code: set.seed(1) vals <- c(rnorm(100), 10, -10) outlier(vals) #>   [1] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE #>  [13] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE #>  [25] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE #>  [37] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE #>  [49] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE #>  [61] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE #>  [73] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE #>  [85] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE #>  [97] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE  TRUE  TRUE outlier(vals, rpt = TRUE) #>     lower     upper  #> -2.358805  2.527535

what: Print a sumry Summarization for Linear Model Objects — print.sumry.lm
title: Print a sumry Summarization for Linear Model Objects — print.sumry.lm
text: Prints comprehensive summary objects class summary.lm lm, including model statistics, ANOVA table, coefficients, optional tables (correlations, covariance, fits), followed five-number summary residuals model call.

title: Print a sumry Summarization for Linear Model Objects — print.sumry.lm
code: # S3 method for class 'sumry.lm' print(   x,   ...,   digits = max(5, getOption("digits") - 2),   symbolic.cor = NULL,   signif.stars = getOption("show.signif.stars"),   options = NULL,   na.print = "",   eps = .Machine$double.eps )

title: Print a sumry Summarization for Linear Model Objects — print.sumry.lm
text: x object class sumry.lm lm. ... Additional arguments (currently used). digits Minimal number significant digits. Defaults max(5, getOption("digits") - 2). symbolic.cor implemented. Defaults NULL. signif.stars Logical; whether show significance stars coefficients table. Defaults getOption("show.signif.stars"). options character vector optional summary tables print (e.g., "v.correlation", "cov.unscaled", "correlation", "fits"). Printed given order present. na.print String use NA values tables. eps Smallest positive floating-point value, used formatting near-zero residuals. Defaults .Machine$double.eps.

title: Print a sumry Summarization for Linear Model Objects — print.sumry.lm
text: Invisibly return unmodified object included call.

title: Print a sumry Summarization for Linear Model Objects — print.sumry.lm
text: function prints summary statistics, ANOVA, coefficients tables linear model order, along specified optional tables provided. concludes five-number-plus-mean summary residuals model call.

title: Print a sumry Summarization for Linear Model Objects — print.sumry.lm
code: mdl <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width, data = iris) sumry(mdl) #>  #> Summary Statistics: #>                  Value      Performance      Measure  Err(Resids)   Metric #> Observations =     150      R-Squared =     0.013823       MAPE =  0.11751 #> F-Statistic =   2.0744      Adj-R2 =       0.0071593       MAD  =   0.6749 #> Pr(b's=0) =      0.152      Std.Err.Est =     0.8251       RMSE =  0.81958 #>  #> Analysis of Variance: #>                Deg.Frdm  Sum.of.Sqs  Mean.Sum.Sqs  F.statistic  p-value(F)     #> Regression            1      1.4122       1.41224       2.0744       0.152     #> Error(Resids)       148    100.7561       0.68078                              #> Total               149    102.1683                                            #>  #> Coefficients: #>              Coefficient  Std.Error   t-stat  p-value      VIF #> (Intercept)      6.52622    0.47890  13.6276   <2e-16 ***      #> Sepal.Width     -0.22336    0.15508  -1.4403    0.152          #>                                                                       #> Signif.Levels:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘** ’ 0.01 ‘ * ’ 0.05 ‘ . ’ 0.1 ‘   ’ 1 #>                                                            #> Summary of   Min     1Q    Median   Mean     3Q      Max   #> Residuals: -1.556  -0.6333 -0.112  <3e-14  0.5579   2.223  #>                                                              #> Call:  lm(formula = Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width, data = iris) sumry(mdl, options = c("correlation", "fits")) #>  #> Summary Statistics: #>                  Value      Performance      Measure  Err(Resids)   Metric #> Observations =     150      R-Squared =     0.013823       MAPE =  0.11751 #> F-Statistic =   2.0744      Adj-R2 =       0.0071593       MAD  =   0.6749 #> Pr(b's=0) =      0.152      Std.Err.Est =     0.8251       RMSE =  0.81958 #>  #> Analysis of Variance: #>                Deg.Frdm  Sum.of.Sqs  Mean.Sum.Sqs  F.statistic  p-value(F)     #> Regression            1      1.4122       1.41224       2.0744       0.152     #> Error(Resids)       148    100.7561       0.68078                              #> Total               149    102.1683                                            #>  #> Coefficients: #>              Coefficient  Std.Error   t-stat  p-value      VIF #> (Intercept)      6.52622    0.47890  13.6276   <2e-16 ***      #> Sepal.Width     -0.22336    0.15508  -1.4403    0.152          #>                                                                       #> Signif.Levels:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘** ’ 0.01 ‘ * ’ 0.05 ‘ . ’ 0.1 ‘   ’ 1 #>                                                            #> Summary of   Min     1Q    Median   Mean     3Q      Max   #> Residuals: -1.556  -0.6333 -0.112  <3e-14  0.5579   2.223  #>                                                              #> Call:  lm(formula = Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width, data = iris)

what: Print Method for Best Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — print.sumry.regsubsets
title: Print Method for Best Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — print.sumry.regsubsets
text: Prints summary objects class summary.regsubsets regsubsets (leaps package), showing model selection statistics best subsets, including R-squared, adjusted R-squared, standard error estimate, Mallows' Cp, AIC.

title: Print Method for Best Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — print.sumry.regsubsets
code: # S3 method for class 'sumry.regsubsets' print(x, ...)

title: Print Method for Best Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — print.sumry.regsubsets
text: x object class summary.regsubsets regsubsets. ... Additional arguments (currently used).

title: Print Method for Best Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — print.sumry.regsubsets
text: Invisibly return object printed.

title: Print Method for Best Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — print.sumry.regsubsets
text: function prints model call table summarizing best models selected, including number predictors, R-squared, adjusted R-squared, standard error estimate (SEE), Mallows' Cp, included variables. input regsubsets object, converted sumry(). , object returned unmodified.

title: Print Method for Best Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — print.sumry.regsubsets

what: Print a Table from Linear Model Summary — print.table.sumry.lm
title: Print a Table from Linear Model Summary — print.table.sumry.lm
text: Prints formatted table sumry linear model, including coefficients, ANOVA, correlation matrices, summary statistics. Significance stars legends added appropriate.

title: Print a Table from Linear Model Summary — print.table.sumry.lm
code: # S3 method for class 'table.sumry.lm' print(   x,   ...,   digits = max(4, getOption("digits") - 2),   quote = FALSE,   na.print = "",   zero.print = "0",   right = TRUE,   justify = "right",   signif.stars = getOption("show.signif.stars"),   eps = .Machine$double.eps,   nsmall = 4,   prnt.lgnd = c("coefficients"),   dig.test = max(1, min(5, digits - 2)) )

title: Print a Table from Linear Model Summary — print.table.sumry.lm
text: x table object linear model sumry (e.g., coefficients, ANOVA, statistics, correlation matrices). ... Additional arguments (currently used). digits Number significant digits print. Defaults max(4, getOption("digits") - 2). quote Logical; whether print quotes (default: FALSE). na.print String use NA values (default: "). zero.print String use 0 values (default: 0). right Logical, indicating whether strings right aligned (default: TRUE). justify Justification columns ("right" "left"; default: "right"). signif.stars Logical; whether show significance stars p-values (default: getOption("show.signif.stars")). eps Smallest positive floating-point value formatting near-zero p-values (default: .Machine$double.eps). nsmall Minimum number digits right decimal point (default: 4). prnt.lgnd Character vector naming tables print significance legends (default: "coefficients"). dig.test Digits hypothesis test statistics (default: max(1, min(5, digits - 2))).

title: Print a Table from Linear Model Summary — print.table.sumry.lm
text: Invisibly returns input table.

title: Print a Table from Linear Model Summary — print.table.sumry.lm
text: method handles tabular output linear model sumry.lm, including coefficients, ANOVA, statistics, correlation/covariance matrices. formats p-values, adds significance stars, prints appropriate legends hypothesis tests.

title: Print a Table from Linear Model Summary — print.table.sumry.lm
code: mdl <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width, data = iris) sum_mdl <- sumry(mdl) print(sum_mdl$coefficients) #>              Coefficient  Std.Error   t-stat  p-value      VIF #> (Intercept)      6.52622    0.47890  13.6276   <2e-16 ***      #> Sepal.Width     -0.22336    0.15508  -1.4403    0.152          #>                                                                       #> Signif.Levels:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘** ’ 0.01 ‘ * ’ 0.05 ‘ . ’ 0.1 ‘   ’ 1

what: Summary Descriptive Statistics for List or Data Frame — sumry.default
title: Summary Descriptive Statistics for List or Data Frame — sumry.default
text: Computes prints summary descriptive statistics variable data frame, list, vector including counts, numeric summaries (min, quartiles, mean, max, standard deviation), factor summaries (levels frequencies).

title: Summary Descriptive Statistics for List or Data Frame — sumry.default
code: # Default S3 method sumry(   x,   ...,   transpose = FALSE,   pad = 2,   maxsum = 10,   opts = list(digits = 4, scipen = 2) )

title: Summary Descriptive Statistics for List or Data Frame — sumry.default
text: x data frame, list, vector containing variables summarize. vector treated single variable data frame. Unnamed variables receive generic names like V1, V2, etc. ... Additional arguments (currently used). transpose logical controlling report format. default table printed organized show variables columns statistic values rows. Setting transpose = TRUE prints transposed table variables rows statistics columns. pad positive integer number spaces output columns. maxsum positive integer limiting number levels factor reports. opts key=value type list, optional input options values output. Existing values restored exit.

title: Summary Descriptive Statistics for List or Data Frame — sumry.default
text: Invisibly returns list containing summary data frame variable rounding. example,  smry <- sumry.df(df[c("", "B", "C")]); smry$$std.dev gives standard deviation variable data frame df

title: Summary Descriptive Statistics for List or Data Frame — sumry.default
text: variable x, function computes count non-missing missing values. Numeric variables summarized minimum, first quartile, median, mean, third quartile, maximum, standard deviation. Factor, logical, character variables summarized level frequencies, level names may abbreviated readability. Results formatted table printed. function returns list containing numeric factor summaries variable.

title: Summary Descriptive Statistics for List or Data Frame — sumry.default
code: sumry(penguins) #>              species       island  bill_len  bill_dep  flipper_len  body_mass #> n.val            344          344       342       342          342        342 #> n.na               0            0         2         2            2          2 #> min      n.lvl  :  3  n.lvl  :  3      32.1      13.1          172       2700 #> Q1       Adelie :152  Biscoe :168      39.2     15.45          190       3550 #> median   Gentoo :124  Dream  :124     44.45      17.3          197       4050 #> mean     Chnstrp: 68  Torgrsn: 52     43.92     17.15        200.9       4202 #> Q3                                     48.5      18.7          214       4800 #> max                                    59.6      21.5          231       6300 #> std.dev                                5.46     1.975        14.06        802 #>                 sex    year #> n.val           333     344 #> n.na             11       0 #> min      n.lvl :  2    2007 #> Q1       male  :168    2007 #> median   female:165    2008 #> mean                   2008 #> Q3                     2009 #> max                    2009 #> std.dev              0.8184 sumry(data.frame(a = rnorm(100),                  b = c(NA, 1:98, NA),                  c = sample(letters[4:6], 100, TRUE)),                  transpose = TRUE, pad = 1) #>     n.val n.na    min      Q1 median    mean     Q3   max std.dev #> a     100    0 -2.592 -0.5068 0.1168 0.08056 0.7844 2.649   1.014 #> b      98    2      1      25   49.5    49.5     74    98   28.43 #> c n.lvl:3    0      3    d:38   e:34    f:28

title: Summary Descriptive Statistics for BAQM — sumry

title: Summary Descriptive Statistics for BAQM — sumry
code: sumry(x, ...)

title: Summary Descriptive Statistics for BAQM — sumry
text: x object summarize; methods available data frames, lists, vectors, linear regression models (lm), best subsets models (regsubsets leaps package). ... Additional arguments passed specific methods.

title: Summary Descriptive Statistics for BAQM — sumry

title: Summary Descriptive Statistics for BAQM — sumry

what: Method sumry to Summarize Linear Model (lm) Objects — sumry.lm
title: Method sumry to Summarize Linear Model (lm) Objects — sumry.lm
text: Computes comprehensive summary object class lm, including performance statistics, ANOVA, coefficients VIFs, correlation/covariance tables. Handles factor variable recoding collinearity/singularity warnings.

title: Method sumry to Summarize Linear Model (lm) Objects — sumry.lm
code: # S3 method for class 'lm' sumry(x, ...)

title: Method sumry to Summarize Linear Model (lm) Objects — sumry.lm
text: x object class lm. ... Additional arguments (currently unused).

title: Method sumry to Summarize Linear Model (lm) Objects — sumry.lm
text: object class sumry.lm containing tables statistics described .

title: Method sumry to Summarize Linear Model (lm) Objects — sumry.lm
text: returned sumry object includes: stats: Performance statistics (F-statistic, R-squared, RMSE, etc.) anova: Simplified ANOVA table (Sum squares, mean squares, F-statistic, p-value) coefficients: Table regression coefficients standard errors, t-stats, p-values, VIFs cov.unscaled, correlation: Covariance correlation matrices coefficients v.correlation: Variable correlation matrix (models interaction terms) fits: Observed, fitted, residual values aliased: Logical vector indicating aliased coefficients df: Degrees freedom sigma: Estimated standard deviation residuals r.squared, adj.r.squared: R-squared adjusted R-squared fstatistic, f.pval: F-statistic p-value overall regression notes: Warnings, singularity, collinearity notes (attached attribute) Factor variable names recoded clarity, coefficients aliased singular variables omitted notes produced attributes.

title: Method sumry to Summarize Linear Model (lm) Objects — sumry.lm
code: mdl <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width + Petal.Length, data = iris) sumry(mdl) #>  #> Summary Statistics: #>                  Value      Performance    Measure  Err(Resids)    Metric #> Observations =     150      R-Squared =    0.84018       MAPE =  0.045172 #> F-Statistic =   386.39      Adj-R2 =        0.8380       MAD  =   0.26563 #> Pr(b's=0) =     <2e-16 ***  Std.Err.Est =  0.33329       RMSE =   0.32994 #>  #> Analysis of Variance: #>                Deg.Frdm  Sum.of.Sqs  Mean.Sum.Sqs  F.statistic  p-value(F)     #> Regression            2      85.840      42.91978       386.39      <2e-16 *** #> Error(Resids)       147      16.329       0.11108                              #> Total               149     102.168                                            #>  #> Coefficients: #>               Coefficient  Std.Error   t-stat   p-value         VIF #> (Intercept)       2.24914   0.247970   9.0702  7.04e-16 ***         #> Sepal.Width       0.59552   0.069328   8.5899  1.16e-14 ***  1.2248 #> Petal.Length      0.47192   0.017118  27.5692   < 2e-16 ***  1.2248 #>                                                                       #> Signif.Levels:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘** ’ 0.01 ‘ * ’ 0.05 ‘ . ’ 0.1 ‘   ’ 1 #>                                                                        #> Summary of    Min       1Q       Mean     Median      3Q        Max    #> Residuals:  -0.9616   -0.2349   <3e-14   0.0007718  0.2145    0.7856   #>                                                                             #> Call:  lm(formula = Sepal.Length ~ Sepal.Width + Petal.Length, data = iris)

what: Summary for Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — sumry.regsubsets
title: Summary for Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — sumry.regsubsets
text: Generates BAQM summary objects class regsubsets (leaps package), showing model selection statistics best subsets, including R-squared, adjusted R-squared, standard error estimate, Mallows' Cp, AIC.

title: Summary for Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — sumry.regsubsets
code: # S3 method for class 'regsubsets' sumry(x, ...)

title: Summary for Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — sumry.regsubsets
text: x object class regsubsets. ... Additional arguments (currently used).

title: Summary for Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — sumry.regsubsets
text: Returns matrix containing summary table best subsets analysis. row summarizes model showing: number predictors, k, used; "best" model k; performance statistics (see ); series columns asterisks indicating specific predictors included model.

title: Summary for Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — sumry.regsubsets
text: function formats table summarizing best models selected, including number predictors, R-squared, adjusted R-squared, standard error estimate (SEE), Mallows' Cp, included variables. first converted summary.regsubsets summary(). , object returned unmodified.

title: Summary for Subset Selection (regsubsets) Objects — sumry.regsubsets
